comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
The clock on the station says 3.55pm, but there are no passengers to be  seen, just railway staff staring at the camera, and enough locomotives to delight any trainspotter.  Very odd!

The <del>original</del> second station (on the left) was a very handsome neo-classical temple.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Locomotive No.1 (centre of photo) is now in the Powerhouse Museum. Full details and heaps of photos: www.powerhousemuseum.com/collection/database/?irn=19352 I see from the blurb (there is a lot of information there) that this locomotive "was withdrawn from service in 1877 after 22 years of operation, having travelled 155 667 miles (250 468 km)". Which suggests that this photo is earlier than 1877 (No.1 looks in great condition here), much earlier than most of the Tyrrell Collection. I hope the experts at the Powerhouse Museum know about this photo!

Is there any reaction from the curators to this important early photo of one of your main exhibits,  Locomotive No.1 ?

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/32162360@N00]

I've dug up some information on some of the locomotives

No 1 - entered service 29/3/1855 withdrawn 15/3/1877
No 2 - entered service 26/9/1855 withdrawn Dec 1879 (hauled first train in NSW)
No 4 - entered service mid 1855 withdrawn before Dec 1879
No 23 - Entered service Sept 1865 withdrawn Dec 1921

More research needed on Nos 51, 57 and 65

Also I notice that No 1 is not steaming, whereas Nos 2 and 4 are, could it be that No 1 was shunted into position for the purpose of the shot (I note that 1, 2 and 4 are at the front of the line ups - as is 23-  ie the oldest engines in the fleet are in front).

Don't know if this is helpful but it might narrow things down a bit ... ie the shot foreseeably could have been taken between 15/3/77 and 12/79. Your idea of a "retirement" picture makes sense.

I wonder if the lads at the ARHS (Australian Railway Historical Society) have done any work on this!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper] Good work!

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/32162360@N00]

Have now discovered that Nos 51 and 57 in all likelihood belonged to the (I)48 class and No 65 to the (O)60 class - all pre-1924 numbering -so I now have something definitive to work on when tracking down service dates ... stay tuned.

(Have spoken to the ARHS today and in all likelihood they have files on such things, but will try my own resources first!)

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper] There is a new post on the blog, explaining how the curator arrived at the 1875 date. Evidently Loco No.65 started service in 1875. www.powerhousemuseum.com/imageservices/index.php/2011/04/...

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/32162360@N00] All this seems to be very plausible ... but I'll continue the hunt! I've now found pictures of other members of the (I) 48 class (look closely on the funnel 5?) investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... and the (O) 60 class investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... On the hunt! But it can be confusing - the NSW Railways have had three numbering systems during their existence; and have been prone to repeat numbers (there were three No 6s) at one stage they had two locomotives running around he system with the same number. Added to that locomotives on the Northern system (ie out of Newcastle) had their own numbering system (No 1N, Class 10N etc) until the Hawkesbury Bridge was built ... after which the two sets of locos intermingled adding still more confusion! To illustrate the point that things aren't always what they a seem - here is a shot captioned "Class Z11 (M40) No.51 locomotive" investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... but it's certainly not the locomotive in the original picture (or is it?) Of course it could have been rebuilt and maintained it's original number! Research continues ... (and you thought trams were interesting!)

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/32162360@N00]

Progress report

(a) ARHS Bulletin No 303 of January 1963 shows and reports "No 60, class leader of the six 0-6-0's place in service in 1874, ....' This confirms the Powerhouse's contention, sort of, but raises the possibility that No 65 may have entered service in 1874. Needs confirmation.

(b) ARHS Bulletin No 309 of July 1963 shows Picton Station in 1874 together with 'second No 10' - which indicates to me that re-using numbers may have been more prevalent than I originally thought, see next paragraph.

(c) ARHS Bulletin No 340 of February 1966 states "The last of the 23N class (originally No 51, then 24N, then 408, and, finally No 69) is said to have been written off in March 1900" - this of course raises the question in my mind is this the number 51 in our picture? And what of No 57? Needs confirmation and/or clarification

More to come when I get a chance.

The astonishing detail shows railway lines, tramway lines, station buildings, and turntables etc. The photo was taken from just to the right of the Mortuary Station (still there) looking NE. www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview?pi=nla.map-rm3443-sd&rgn=0...

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/32162360@N00] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/47201412@N02]
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/24785917@N03]

Now back from the ARHS Resource Centre and have some vital information, alas Beachcomber no one offered an opinion, apart from, "probably Railways Department PR" for the reason the picture was taken.  

But have some key dates

Loco No 1 - 1 class - in service 26/4/1855 - withdrawn 6/1877
Loco No 2 - 1 class -  in service 26/9/1855 - withdrawn 1879
Loco No 4 - 1 class - in service 9/1855 - withdrawn  between Jan and Jun 1877 and condemned 7/1877*
Loco No 23 - (G) 23 class - in service 4/1867 - withdrawn 12/1929
Loco No 51 - 23N class - in service 7/1874 - withdrawn 1892
Loco No 57 - (I) 48 class - in service 7/1875 - withdrawn 6/1903
Loco No 65 - (O) 60 class - in service 1/1875 - withdrawn 1/1889

This means that the photograph was taken between the arrival of No 57 (July 1875) and the withdrawal of No 4 (in the first six months of 1877) - ie in the 18 - 24 month period between July 1875 and July 1877. 

Now it happens that the railways were 20 years old on 26/9/1875 .... so I wonder .. a twentieth anniversary picture perhaps? So, it could well be a bit of early Railways Department PR!

(*Not reported above is the history of No 3 which was withdrawn and condemned in January 1877 - in all likelihood No 4 was withdrawn at the same time - but the official records do not indicate this - both Nos 3 and 4 ended up as stationary engines to drive machinery at Sydney Railway Works in 1877)

Other opinions appreciated
